intro: Viola sororia subsp. affinis, commonly known as the eastern violet, is a herbaceous perennial native to eastern North America. It typically grows to a height of 10–20 cm, with heart-shaped, hairy leaves and violet or purple flowers. The plant thrives in moist, shady environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its flowers bloom in early spring, and it produces capsule fruits that contain several seeds. The species is characterized by its distinct leaf morphology and floral structure, making it a recognizable member of the Violaceae family.
